definitions.definition: A situation in which the king is directly threatened by an opposing piece.
An inspection or examination.
definitions.example: I don't know if she will be there, but it's worth a check.

definitions.definition: A control; a limit or stop.
definitions.example: The castle moat should hold the enemy in check.

definitions.definition: A mark (especially a checkmark: ✓) used as an indicator.
definitions.example: Place a check by the things you have done.

definitions.definition: An order to a bank to pay money to a named person or entity.
definitions.example: I was not carrying cash, so I wrote a check for the amount.

definitions.definition: A bill, particularly in a restaurant.
definitions.example: I summoned the waiter, paid the check, and hurried to leave.

definitions.definition: A maneuver performed by a player to take another player out of the play.
definitions.example: The hockey player gave a good hard check to obtain the puck.

definitions.definition: A token used instead of cash in gaming machines, or in gambling generally.
A lengthwise separation through the growth rings in wood.
A mark, certificate or token by which errors may be prevented, or a thing or person may be identified.
The forsaking by a hawk of its proper game to follow other birds.
A small chink or crack.
To inspect; to examine.
definitions.example: Check the oil in your car once a month.

definitions.definition: To verify the accuracy of a text or translation, usually making some corrections (proofread) or many (copyedit).

(often used with "off") To mark items on a list (with a checkmark or by crossing them out) that have been chosen for keeping or removal or that have been dealt with (for example, completed or verified as correct or satisfactory).
definitions.example: Check off the items that you've checked (inspected).

definitions.definition: To control, limit, or halt.
definitions.example: Check your enthusiasm during a negotiation.

definitions.definition: To verify or compare with a source of information.
definitions.example: Check your data against known values.

definitions.definition: To leave in safekeeping.
definitions.example: Check your hat and coat at the door.

definitions.definition: To leave with a shipping agent for shipping.
definitions.example: Check your bags at the ticket counter before the flight.

definitions.definition: To pass or bounce the ball to an opponent from behind the three-point line and have the opponent pass or bounce it back to start play.
definitions.example: He checked the ball and then proceeded to perform a perfect layup.

definitions.definition: To disrupt another player with the stick or body to obtain possession of the ball or puck.
definitions.example: The hockey player checked the defenceman to obtain the puck.

definitions.definition: To remain in a hand without betting. Only legal if no one has yet bet.
definitions.example: Tom didn't think he could win, so he checked.

definitions.definition: To make a move which puts an adversary's king in check; to put in check.
To chide, rebuke, or reprove.
To slack or ease off, as a brace which is too stiffly extended.
To crack or gape open, as wood in drying; or to crack in small checks, as varnish, paint, etc.
To make checks or chinks in; to cause to crack.
To make a stop; to pause; with at.
To clash or interfere.
To act as a curb or restraint.
To turn, when in pursuit of proper game, and fly after other birds.
(usually pluralized) A pattern made up of a grid of squares of alternating colors; a checkered pattern.
definitions.example: The tablecloth had red and white checks.

definitions.definition: Any fabric woven with such a pattern.
To mark with a check pattern.
